Edward Royce (chairman of the committee) presiding. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Chairman Royce">This committee will come to order.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Chairman Royce">There is no doubt democracy is on the ropes. Freedom House reports that democracy has declined worldwide over the last decade.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Chairman Royce">The question for us is do we care? And if so, what should we do about it?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Chairman Royce">We better care. Democracy's expansion brought unprecedented prosperity. America is more secure when fewer nations are authoritarian, which is the unfortunate alternative to democracy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Chairman Royce">Strongmen regimes justify their repression at home by creating enemies abroad. Since the freedom we enjoy is a threat to authoritarian regimes, the U.S. and our allies are natural targets of their aggression.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Chairman Royce">We have seen this with Russia and China and North Korea, and I'd rather trade and do business with a democracy than with a regime.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Chairman Royce">Democracy is morally just. Members of this committee have spent countless hours holding hearings, protesting, and fighting injustice abroad. Human rights are far better protected in democratic countries, ones without dank prison cells full of political prisoners.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Chairman Royce">Democracy is more than just elections. Democracy without the foundation of rule of law or individual liberties, a free press, and a culture of tolerance is dangerous populism or mob rule.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Chairman Royce">We've seen that in Burma, South Sudan, Gaza, and too many other places. Democratic values are universal. Of course, each country will develop democracy in different ways and at a different pace, and we may have differences over how best to promote democracy in various countries, especially given our strategic interests.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Chairman Royce">But we should always remember that, as Ronald Reagan noted in his 1982 Westminster speech, free elections are enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Chairman Royce">At home, we must maintain the decades-old bipartisan consensus that democracy is a core element of U.S. foreign policy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Chairman Royce">That is why it is important to have the National Endowment for Democracy, the International Republican Institute, and the National Democratic Institute here today, and that is why it's important that Congress continues to adequately fund these institutions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Chairman Royce">Promoting democracy is not easy. There are many stresses, including destabilizing mass refugee flows and accelerating economic change.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Chairman Royce">Mistakes have been made, but lessons have been learned. These include the need to promote women in building and supporting democracy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Chairman Royce">Compounding the challenge, authoritarian regimes such as Russia and China are aggressively attacking democracies across the globe, including attacking our own democracy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Chairman Royce">As one witness will note, these attacks are broad, political, economic, and they are cultural. Beijing is spending billions, using the technology revolution to surveille its citizens at home while spreading propaganda abroad.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Chairman Royce">I have seen Moscow's assault on its neighbors firsthand. We better wake up to this threat. Now.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Chairman Royce">For years, our great Nation has inspired countless individuals to seek freedom in their homelands. Some have been tortured, murdered for their democratic commitment.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Chairman Royce">Many have succeeded. Our wonderful legacy of leadership on this issue has given us power and influence. We must protect and nurture our own democracy for that to continue.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Chairman Royce"> And I will momentarily turn to our ranking member, Mr. Eliot Engel from New York, for his opening statement here this morning as well. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Engel</speaker> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Mr. Engel">Thank you, Mr. Chairman, and to our witnesses, welcome. I want to especially thank Ken Wollack for 35 years of service. Congratulations on your retirement in September.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Mr. Engel">Your organizations do incredible work promoting democracy around the world, making governments more accountable and responsive and shining the light on abuses and corruption.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="Mr. Engel">It's such important work because around the world democracy, unfortunately, is backsliding. According to the Freedom in the World report, democracy and global freedom has declined around the world for 12 straight years.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="Mr. Engel">In Africa, while we have seen a slight opening of political systems, in Zimbabwe, Ethiopia, Gambia, and elsewhere, in Burundi, Rwanda, and the Republic of the Congo, the new normal has become constitutional coups, which is term limited incumbents changing the rules so they can stay in power.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="27" speaker="Mr. Engel">When I was in Africa with the chairman we tried to speak to the leadership about this but, of course, they wouldn't speak with us because they knew what we were going to say.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="28" speaker="Mr. Engel">Tanzania and Zambia show warning signs of creeping authoritarianism, and more and more governments are shutting down the internet to stifle dissent and buy time to tamper with election results.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="29" speaker="Mr. Engel">In the Middle East, Tunisia's progress has been inspiring and we should help improve the climate for foreign investment there. But it's another story in Egypt, where draconian laws have limited the ability of civil society to operate.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="30" speaker="Mr. Engel">And I am a friend of Egypt, so it really pains me when I say this. The recent elections in Iraq are overshadowed by reports of fraud, which should be cleared up by full recounts before forming a new government.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="31" speaker="Mr. Engel">Across Europe, democratic practices have steadily eroded. Turkey's President, Erdogan, has consolidated power and cracked down on dissent. It's just really disgraceful what's going on in Turkey.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="32" speaker="Mr. Engel">In Hungary, refugees and migrants face hostility from the higher levels of government. In Poland, free speech and an independent judiciary are under attack.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="33" speaker="Mr. Engel">Now, much of this is driven by Russia, a fake democracy, whose leader, Vladimir Putin, seeks to undermine Western unity and discredit democratic institutions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="34" speaker="Mr. Engel">Since 2014, in Asia, there has been a military coup in Thailand, a populist leader elected in the Philippines, who shoots people on sight because the thinks they are involved with drugs, ethnic cleansing in Burma at the hands of the military--very disappointing.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="35" speaker="Mr. Engel">Cambodia's prime minister of 33 years has neutralized political opposition and China grows more aggressive in oppressing its own citizens, quietly promoting its authoritarian model around the world as an alternative to Western democratic values and chipping away at international norms.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="36" speaker="Mr. Engel">Here in our neighborhood in our hemisphere, Nicholas Maduro has turned Venezuela into a full-blown dictatorship with sham elections, political prisoners, and a denial of the country's humanitarian crisis.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="37" speaker="Mr. Engel">Taken together, these cases and others become a problem for our national security. The United States wants to see vibrant democracies around the world, countries that share our values and priorities.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="38" speaker="Mr. Engel">Strong democracies make strong partners. When we collaborate with like-minded governments, we are better able to meet challenges, project stability, and drive prosperity.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="39" speaker="Mr. Engel">On the other hand, the greatest threats we face come from places where governments are closed off, where human rights aren't a priority, where ordinary citizens have less of a say in choosing their leaders.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="40" speaker="Mr. Engel">These are the places where vulnerable people are exploited and extremism is able to take root. So promoting democracy, helping to advance our democratic values around the world--the work that your three organizations do--as I say to the witnesses--should be at the center of our foreign policy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="41" speaker="Mr. Engel">As I often say, it's the right thing to do because democracy helps people live fuller freer lives and it's also the smart thing to do because democracy is good for our security.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="42" speaker="Mr. Engel">That's why it's baffling that the administration has decided that democracy is no longer a foreign policy priority. The budgets the administration has sent us seek to slash investments in diplomacy and development by a third.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="43" speaker="Mr. Engel">So many of the efforts we make around the world to strengthen democracy would be hobbled if Congress went along with these draconian cuts.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="44" speaker="Mr. Engel">Thankfully, Congress did not. In Nicaragua, for example, 140 people have been killed in the last 2 months, primarily at the hands of President Ortega's thugs.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="45" speaker="Mr. Engel">The White House request for democracy assistance in Nicaragua for next year, zero. The three organizations represented today all rely on Federal grants to carry out their important work. Not if the administration gets its way.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="46" speaker="Mr. Engel">The State Department even removed democracy from its mission statement. What does that say about American values and American leadership?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="47" speaker="Mr. Engel">And on issues like this, leadership starts at the top. Democracy isn't just under attack in distant places. The Economist's Democracy Index recently downgraded the United States to flawed democracy as opposed to a full democracy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="48" speaker="Mr. Engel">Just yesterday, the President tweeted, ``Our country's biggest enemy is the fake news so easily promulgated by fools.''</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="49" speaker="Mr. Engel">Attacking the free press, the way I see it, is an attack on democracy. It's an attack on a fundamental right in this country.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="50" speaker="Mr. Engel">Our President has spoken glowingly of Vladimir Putin, Saddam Hussein, Erdogan, Duterte in the Philippines, Xi in China, and, of course, in Singapore, he had nothing but kind words for Kim Jong-un, a brutal dictator, a murderer, who rules over the most oppressive system in the world, all while attacking America's closest friends like Canada.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="51" speaker="Mr. Engel">So the world looks to us to set an example, to show leadership, to advance our interests in a way that respects the dignity and rights of all people, and right now, I don't believe we are sending the right message.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="52" speaker="Mr. Engel">So I look forward to hearing from our witnesses about how we can get back on track and revitalize democracy as part of our foreign policy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="53" speaker="Mr. Engel"> I thank you, again, Mr. Chairman, and I yield back. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="54" speaker="Chairman Royce">Thank you, Mr. Engel.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="55" speaker="Chairman Royce">This morning, I am pleased to welcome our distinguished guests here on the panel, including Mr. Carl Gershman, who has served as president of the National Endowment for Democracy since its founding in 1984.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="56" speaker="Chairman Royce">He's a long-time friend of this committee. He's respected worldwide for his work, especially in his efforts to help peaceably end the Cold War and transition countries from behind the Iron Curtain to democracy, and he's done this through nongovernmental action.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="57" speaker="Chairman Royce">Before his time at NED, he was the senior counselor to the United States representative to the United Nations, where he worked on international human rights issues.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="58" speaker="Chairman Royce">Mr. Daniel Twining is the president of the International Republican Institute and previously he served as the counselor and director of the Asia program at the German Marshall Fund of the United States. He also worked here in Congress as a foreign policy advisor to Senator John McCain.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="59" speaker="Chairman Royce">And we have Mr. Kenneth Wollack. He is president of the National Democratic Institute, and he has co-edited the Middle East Policy Survey and written regularly on foreign affairs for the Los Angeles times.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="60" speaker="Chairman Royce">We wish him well on his retirement, but we are going to miss his active expertise on so many issues.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="61" speaker="Chairman Royce">We appreciate all of you being here today, especially given the contributions the three of you have made, and without objection, the witnesses' full prepared statements will be made part of the record.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="62" speaker="Chairman Royce">Members here will have 5 legislative, or calendar, days to submit statements and questions and extraneous material for the record.</paragraph>
Hearing.Statement: <opening>STATEMENT OF MR. CARL GERSHMAN, PRESIDENT, NATIONAL ENDOWMENTFOR DEMOCRACY</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="MR. CARL GERSHMAN"> So if you would, Mr. Gershman, please summarize your remarks and after we hear from the panel we will go to our questions. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Gershman</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Gershman">Thank you, Mr. Chairman, and thank you for your long leadership and for your commitment to the cause of democracy throughout the world. We deeply appreciate it.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Gershman">I agree with you that democracy is on the ropes. Freedom House data and so forth, resurgent authoritarianism, democratic backsliding in many countries, the sharp power phenomenon that we have called attention to.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Gershman">But I want to devote myself this morning, if I may, to a more positive narrative, to take a look at something that I would call democratic resilience and also authoritarian vulnerability, and then what we can do practically to help, because I think it would be a mistake to assume that the decline of a democracy is inevitable or irreversible.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Gershman">I'd call your attention, for example, to some recent events, among them the remarkable democratic transition in Gambia; the fall of the corrupt Zuma government in South Africa; the stunning victory of democracy in Malaysia, and the freeing of opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim; the equally stunning triumph of democracy in Armenia; and the successful local elections in Tunisia that are, in my view, a decisive step forward in the Arab world's first democracy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Gershman">These are just a few of the examples that I could give of recent democratic advances. There is Slovakia, interesting developments in Ethiopia. Even in a country like Uzbekistan we can see some glimmerings of some opening.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Gershman">They show that we should never underestimate the desire of ordinary people for freedom and dignity or the extent of the anger at corrupt and unresponsive government officials.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Gershman">On the question of authoritarian vulnerability, the Islamic Republic of Iran, for example, is a failed system, in my view, which was shown by the protests that swept over the country less than 6 months ago and that will certainly recur.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Gershman">The Bolivarian dictatorship in Venezuela and the Ortega regime in Nicaragua are also, in my view, failed systems, not to mention the Cuban and North Korean dictatorships as well as the stagnant Russian kleptocracy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Gershman">China is projecting its military and economic power and threatening to spread its model of the totalitarian surveillance state.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Gershman">But while Xi's regime may claim performance legitimacy because of its economic growth, it lacks political legitimacy. Why must Xi prohibit what he calls historical nihilism, meaning any discussion of the Tiananmen Square massacre or the Maoist disaster like the Cultural Revolution and the Great Leap Forward?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Gershman">Why has it been necessary to eliminate a political dissident like Nobel Laureate Liu Xiaobo, to arrest hundreds of human rights lawyers, suppress the Christian house church movement in China and expunge the cultural and religious identity of Tibetan and Uighur minorities?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Gershman">By stoking nationalism to fill the void left by the death of Communist ideology, the regime just exposes its failure to develop values with broad appeal.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Gershman">Why, therefore, should we assume that the so-called China model will not also end up as Reagan said in that Westminster address ``on the ash heap of history?''</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Gershman">We must not underestimate the immense challenge of building and consolidating stable democracies, and Congressman Engel referred to that.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Gershman">Democracy is hard work, especially in countries that are poor and that have experienced violent conflict, and it takes time and a great deal of effort.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Mr. Gershman">That means helping the people who share our democratic values and who want to build free societies governed by the rule of law is something we have to do.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Mr. Gershman">And so it is in that spirit that the NED and its institutes helps the kind of activists we honored last night, Mr. Chairman, and thank you for speaking at our event last night with the NED's Democracy Awardees who are fighting to rescue the people of North Korea from enslavement and it's remarkable work that they do and which we are supporting.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Mr. Gershman">It's why we have supported people like Cynthia Gabriel, one of the recipients of last year's Democracy Award, who led the effort to expose the massive corruption associated with the 1MDB scandal in Malaysia--Raphael Marques, another award recipient last year, who has led the fight against equally massive corruption in Angola and who is now on trial for allegedly insulting corrupt officials.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Mr. Gershman">Other examples include the support that NED has given in Ukraine to the Anti-Corruption Action Center that has tirelessly led the campaign for the establishment of an independent anti-corruption court, and I am pleased to report that just last week the Ukrainian Parliament at long last approved legislation to create such a court.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Mr. Gershman">Another important victory just occurred in Afghanistan where a daily newspaper that we support published an investigative report on the illegal issuance of diplomatic passports to Afghan strongmen and the government immediately cancelled over 4,000 such passports in Afghanistan.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Mr. Gershman">The last example is the nonpartisan training conducted by four NGOs in Tunisia of new candidates who participated in last month's local elections. Of the 235 individuals who were trained, 112 won seats and 25 were at the heads of their electoral lists.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Mr. Gershman">These elections have made democracy in Tunisia more inclusive and responsive, dealing a blow to ISIS, which has been able to recruit young people in Tunisia who are frustrated over the failure of the revolution to produce meaningful social and economic change.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Mr. Gershman">Mr. Chairman, I could go on and give many other examples of dedicated NED grantees whose work is advancing American values and security around the world.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="Mr. Gershman">Our job is to empower such brave people and to let them know that they are not alone because they have the support of the American people and the American Congress, of course.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="Mr. Gershman">This, I believe, is what Reagan meant when he said at Westminster that as important as military strength is, and I quote,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="27" speaker="Mr. Gershman">``The ultimate determinant in the struggle that is now</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="28" speaker="Mr. Gershman">going on in the world will not be bombs and rockets but</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="29" speaker="Mr. Gershman">a test of wills and ideas, a trial of spiritual</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="30" speaker="Mr. Gershman">resolve, the values we hold, the beliefs we cherish,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="31" speaker="Mr. Gershman">and the ideals to which we are dedicated.''</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="32" speaker="Mr. Gershman">We can win this test of wills and ideas if we have the spiritual resolve to fight and to stand with the people and support people around the world who are struggling to build democratic societies.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="33" speaker="Mr. Gershman">If we do this, we will make the world a safer and more peaceful place and the values upon which this Nation is founded will be strengthened as well.</paragraph>

Thank you.</paragraph>

<opening>STATEMENT OF MR. DANIEL TWINING, PRESIDENT, INTERNATIONALREPUBLICAN INSTITUTE</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="MR. DANIEL TWINING"> Dan Twining. Say, Dan, turn that up or hit the button. There we go. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Twining</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Twining">Got it. Got it.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Twining">Thank you to all of you, the chairman and the ranking member, so many of you and so many in this body, for representing not only our country's interest out in the world but the values that reinforce those interests, and I would like to argue that those aren't separate things but one and the same.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Twining">Last month, IRI honored Jim Mattis and Nikki Haley at our annual Freedom Dinner. We appreciated Chairman Royce's participation, and other members of this committee.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Twining">Secretary Mattis shared an observation that speaks to the heart of why America supports democracy in the world. Here's what he said:</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Twining">``I have many privileged glimpses into the human</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Twining">condition, but I've never once seen human beings flee</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Twining">the freedom of speech.
